Body:
I'm not familiar with Welsh, so make some general remarks.

If you assume that the unmarked form in a paradigm is the most basic, and that all morphological signs are marked by the addition of phonological material, then you arrive at the singulative analysis. If you instead would like to assume that the singular form in the paradigm is the most basic, then you are required to admit morphological operations such as subtraction, truncation, and ellipsis. If you read French and have access to a university library, consider looking in Mel'cuk's Cours de morphologie générale on the topic, or that failing, find a copy of his more condensed and more widely available English work, Aspects of the Theory of Morphology.
